title: 105_hr973
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jesse Gray Housing Act" and includes findings and purposes. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" finds that there is a shortage of rental units for lower-income families, with many units in poor condition. Federal housing assistance programs often benefit middle and higher income families instead of meeting the needs of lower income families. These programs are not cost-effective due to a lack of suitable rental units, leading to many families spending more than 25 percent of their income on rent. The Act aims to ensure all families in the United States have access to affordable housing. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" aims to ensure affordable rental units for all families in the United States, limiting housing assistance to lower income families and promoting a public housing system with visually indistinguishable units. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" promotes a public housing system with units that are visually indistinguishable from privately owned dwelling units. The "Jesse Gray Housing Act" promotes public housing construction of 500,000 new dwelling units annually from 1998 to 2007, with necessary appropriations authorized. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to provide financial assistance for public housing projects at risk of demolition or disposition, with a preference for projects under the Jesse Gray Housing Act. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to increase budget authority for contracts for annual contributions to revitalize 100,000 public housing units each fiscal year from 1998 to 2007. SEC. 5 prohibits the demolition and disposition of public housing projects without authorization. It also includes conforming amendments to the United States Housing Act of 1937. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to lower income housing requirements from 30 to 25 in various sections. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to lower income housing requirements from 30 to 25 in various sections related to public housing, supportive housing for the elderly and persons with disabilities, the HOME Program, and rent supplements. The Development Act of 1965, National Housing Act, Housing and Community Development Amendments of 1978, and Housing and Urban-Rural Recovery Act of 1983 are amended to lower income housing requirements from 30 to 25 in various sections. The Low-Income Housing Preservation and Resident Homeownership Act of 1990, State Preservation Project Assistance, and Preserving Existing Housing Investment are amended to lower income housing requirements from 30 to 25 in various sections. The Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1997, Emergency Low Income Housing Preservation Act of 1987, HOPE Homeownership Programs, and Native American Housing Assistance Act are all amended to reduce income housing requirements from 30 to 25 percent. The Development, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 1997, Emergency Low Income Housing Preservation Act of 1987, HOPE Homeownership Programs, and Native American Housing Assistance Act are all amended to reduce income housing requirements from 30 to 25 percent. Various housing acts are also amended to change the percentage from 30 to 25 in different sections. The Federal Home Loan Bank Act, Federal Deposit Insurance Act, and Community Development Block Grants are all amended to reduce certain percentages from 30 to 25 in specific sections. The Federal Home Loan Bank Act, Federal Deposit Insurance Act, and Community Development Block Grants are amended to reduce percentages from 30 to 25 in specific sections related to emergency relief demonstration and exclusion of certain income for families. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 1997. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will submit a report to Congress proposing to limit Federal housing assistance to public housing to ensure funds benefit lower income families.
